At a good price. I recommend it 7-9/10 in it's own way. I just wish there were more travel locations and foods. The game mentions the usual attractions and a story between you and these two. However replayable is necessary due to limited days. Locations include popular shrines, Akihabara, Shibuya's Hachiko, and Mt. Fuji. In it's right, it's worth the buy and on average it's short but educational. Plus those who want to take a look into Japan, this is a more accurate version with the matters of scenery, travel, and places. If you do go and don't know anyone, grab a guide and trust me you won't regret it. Just remember though don't think too high and bring a lot of cash. Trust me this game may keep the rate the same but in RL, the exchange rates can change so fast during hours of the day. If I were to give it a score. 6.4-8 due to it's playthrough, limited area, good story, dialogue, but it lacks location, extended travel days, and covers one area. Yet as it is a game, I can say it did it's job right with the guides. So for in total the average would be a 7.5-7.8. Although this game was released in 2011, adding it here will help those who didn't know much. Either way enjoy the game for what it is. I know I did, just wished that we had another version, different guides, different area, you know. Needs that litle extra. Still good in it's own right. Enjoyable.

Go! Go! Nippon! is a short Visual Novel based on the idea of someone visiting Japan for the first time.   Of course you as the main character speak really good Japanese, and is also an Otaku. The story is mostly centered around you exploring Japan in the company of two girls who take turns going with you depending on where you decide to visit. The nudity tag doesn't really belong on this game but whatever.  Personally the story felt as if it was a bit lacking because of the nature of the premise: visiting Japan for the first time. There are few choices that you can make that make any difference and only two endings.   Overall it can be an entertaining game if you're in the right mood, just don't expect much from it. If you want to visit Japan though, it has cool features like being able to hit a button and see what that specific location looks like on google maps from a street view. I found this to be interesting as I wouldn't know exactly where to look for those specific attractions.   Though it's not amazing, it's still worth the playthrough twice if you get it at a discount on the base price. If you're VN lover, you'd probably rate it higher than my 5/10.   [This review is not based on the content in the DLC]

For a limited time offer, not only do you get one waifu, but two waifus at 50% off!  This game teaches a some what wide range of tourism in Japan. For this limited sale, it is definitely worth it for the empty souled 2D-lover, aspiring Japanese future-tourist, or/and curious buyer.

This game is my first visual novel, so I can't compare it to others. As a standalone experience, it's interesting. You play a tourist coming to Japan for the first time, staying with a couple of brothers you met on the Internet. The brothers turn out to be sisters - shocking! and also, you forgot to ask and apparently never shared a pronoun - and in among the inevitable progress to seduction (you only get to fall for one of them per game) there's a lot of first-time tourist information about visiting Tokyo and the environs, along with light language lessons and some good practical advice about tourist mistakes to avoid. Which is actually pretty cool. I've never been, but now I'm quite curious.   There's no nudity; the Steam game tag is wrong on this score. You manage to catch each sister minus some clothing by forgetting to knock and then forgetting to look away or close the door, but the pictures are PG-13 in nature, if not intent. Apart from that it's all about True Love, and in fact the game gets embarrassed pretty easily, like if anything ever even remotely suggests that people might be physically attracted to each other. The number of awkward-pause ellipse screens to click past [...] is staggering.   There are two endings (one each for matching with each of the sisters), and if you check a game guide, as I did after my first play-through, a couple of judicious saves and liberal use of the 'Skip' button will let you play quickly to the other ending and give you the couple of scenes you missed by choosing this restaurant instead of that one, and so forth. Acing one or two of these alternatives unlocks extras that will let you look at the pictures of your times with Makoto and Akira, replay scenes, and give you an index of information about the sites you visited - you can also click through in-game to Googlemaps pictures of the places you go.   The game definitely wants you to end up with one sister rather than the other, or so it seemed to me. They will both fall for you if they're called on to do so, but one harbors a quiet crush and the other is all 'Hi, I'm the hot one but don't let me near the kitchen.' Goofy, but absorbing.

This game is a general tour guide being packed as visual novel. A bit romantic sauce here and there as to be expected from VNs.   You play as a guy who's going on a trip to Japan. During the trip you'll stay in the house of two girls that will act as your tour guides throughout the game. The game will introduce Japan's various vacation / historical / interesting spots and depict them to you through these two girls. You will make some choices of where to go, limited in one playthrough so you need multiple playthrough to visit all places. You might also open Google Maps for the particular places you're currently in the game (there's in-game link to that place's coordinate).  Overall, the graphic, sound and story materials are well done. If you're not familiar at all about Japan, this game will be a good introductory material for you as you won't be bored to death reading some literature or pages from Google. Honestly, I wouldn't have known much more about Japan had it not been because of this game.  Worth playing of course, so recommended.

Short review:   'Go! Go! Nippon!' is an informative, charming and nicely illustrated story. A bit pricy for what you get, but still a great purchase. Get it when it's on sale.  7/10   Longer review:  The story itself is standard. You are a tourist from the west who's lifelong dream is to visit Japan. While he's there he'll be staying with two siblings who he, at first, assumes to be boys but he is later mistaken. It doesn't take long before he settles in, meets his hosts and sets out to see sights and taste food, with great travel advice along the way.  At first the characters, particularly the protagonist, seem like they would get on your nerves, but within about 10 minutes this is sorted out. At first the main character seems to be some kind of hermit, dropping his jaw at everything he sees, but shortly after his arrival he becomes a likeable, if a little bland, character. Nothing worth complaining about, but he's not exactly winning any awards. The two sisters who act as guides for the protagonist have far more personality than he does, and later on in the game you will get quite attached.  'Go! Go! Nippon!' is a great visual novel for those who are interested in visiting Japan. You can set the Dollars or Euros to Yen rate and as you purchase items in the game it will give you a realistic total of what it would cost like in real life. The two sisters guiding you around the various locations of the country have lots to say and you can learn a great deal about the history of both main and hidden-away tourist destinations. I enjoyed this visual novel. It gave me a taste of what the different districts of Tokyo are known for, and provided just the right amout of interesting history behind them without getting lost in details.  This story is about a teenage boy's first trip to Japan to spend with two friends he knows online, Makoto and Akira - but, much to his surprise, they are attractive teenage girls, not boys. Their parents are away, so he spends the week touring various parts of Tokyo with them.  There are six districts to visit; you can choose one to visit on each of the first three days (meaning that you can only see half of them on a single playthrough). Depending on which district you choose, one of the sisters will come along with you for the day (there's no way to know which until after you choose). Days four and five are an overnight trip (via Shinkansen) to Kyoto with both of them, and then day six is spent with whichever girl joined you more often on the first three days, So there's a light romance plot tacked on here that ends up with you falling for whichever sister you spent more time with; there's no real way to choose which one to love, but since Makoto will come with you to three of the districts and Akira to the other three, a second playthrough will let you see the other three districts and the other sister's ending. You've got more say over a few other choices long the way (like, what do you want for dinner: pizza, Japanese pizza, or sushi?). I spent about four hours playing through the story twice (and making liberal use of the handy 'Skip' button the second time through).  One of the story's strengths is that every line is displayed in English, with the Japanese translation of it displayed in kana - very handy if you're learning. Also handy is that the text is displayed in different colors depending on who's speaking it. (No voiceover here, unfortunately.) An odd feature is that it asks for the current dollar/yen exchange rate and then displays your running expenses, so you have an idea how much your trip is costing you. One tidbit I stumbled upon by luck: while there are many ways into the game's menu, the only way out is to right-click. Until I discovered that, I was frustrated at being trapped in the menu.  The only really unfortunate thing about this story is that you'll walk in on one sister bent over in her panties, and the other sister (tastefully) naked. That alone kept me from recommending this to a neighbor's kids before their trip to Japan, and it's a shame, because the rest of the content here might really have interested them.  All in all, 'Go! Go! Nippon!' is the next best thing to taking a tour of Tokyo with somebody who really knows the place and can point out interesting stuff along the way. (And this visual novel is much, much less expensive than a trip to Japan, too.)

After what I believe to be 100% completion of the VN w/o the DLC, I can definitely recommend Go! Go! Nippon! ~My First Trip to Japan~. It appears at first to be a fairly standard dating sim and while that aspect is present in a way, it serves the purpose of educating about the various districts of Tokyo and beyond much more than it sates the dating aspect.   Pros: +Informative- A majority of the places you can see are really fleshed out and given detail, which is very nice. They provide both cultural and historical insight into places that are seen a lot in anime but not explored. It has a good balance of entertaining and informing to maintain the casual atmosphere it generally succeeds in having. +Beautiful- Honestly a lot of the art was just very, very well made and made the experience all the more enjoyable. +Implementation of 'Archetype' Characters- While Makoto and Akira do fall under fairly common stereotypes of characters, the manner in which they operate in the story is unique and responded to their situations really consistently according to their personality. They are endowed with qualities that make them both enjoyable to be with and depending on the route you take, find satisfaction in their endings. +Endings- I thought the endings of Makoto's route was really sweet and Akira's as well in their own different ways that felt really appropriate for how they were characterized.   Cons: +Few choices- Other than where you went, there were few choices that made it feel much less linear than the VN is. The first readthrough took much longer than my second because a lot of interactions up until the last couple of days stay the same. +Derpy Protagonist- At times, it was rather annoying to find the protagonist get excited over literally the smallest details but honestly, as long as you keep an open mind, it's not a deal breaker. +Not Enough Art- There are crucial transition points like on the train when getting an idea of the surrounding is important to learning but alas, they revert to the same shot of the sky as filler for that scene. Again, not a dealbreaker, but just another thing that I felt could have benefitted the VN. +Epilogues- Makoto's was too short and Akira's ending was just a bit too melodramatic for me at first.  Conclusion:  If it's on sale (or even not to be honest), definitely check out Go! Go! Nippon! ~My First Trip to Japan~ and its DLC which I have yet to try. Really informative and entertaining, and while with a few drawbacks, still well worth my time and money!

Go! Go! Nippon! ~My First Trip to Japan~  is an unusual experiment that trades heavily on novelty but fails to leave a lasting impression.   The game presents itself as a tourist guidebook-esque visual novel intended for English-speaking audiences--this being rather alien territory for the genre--with all the trappings of the genre. Indeed, the attractive (albeit limited) art, interface and scenario design are rooted in the traditions of the Japanese visual novel. Unforunately, the experience is too brief and the informational aspect too slim; the game falls short of both of its propositions.   While the premise is intriguing, the characters are archetypal and the attempts at comedy and romance are tired and toneless. The main character--a foreigner homestaying with a pair of Japanese siblings--is merely a palette swap of the garden-variety protagonists found in lesser Japanese visual novels. His amorous leanings disappoint with their banal outcomes, and the girls fare no better. Makoto is a classical Japanese housewife-type whose prinicpal character flaw is an apparent inability to follow a recipe. Akira is a stand-offish, zesty younger sister whose conflicted romantic intentions toward the main character are too expected and textureless to muster any emotion in the player.   The game scenario branches into two storylines focusing on either girl, though the player receives no warning of how the limited choices to be made over the course of the game lead to which unaffecting outcome. The overall narrative has a distinct back-patting tone when mention is made of various technologies employed throughout Tokyo. The protagonist's constant amazement of Japanese technological progress and paradisiacal protrayal of Japanese life should strike any player familiar with the reality of living in Japan as disingenuous and irresponsible.   As a resource for would-be tourists, there is still more disappointment in store. The various guided tours of areas within Tokyo (and a few out-of-prefecture day trips) feel spartan and excessively-curated. Visits to points of interest within a given locale can be counted on one hand, and each day of the week's adventure ends before it seems to have begun. Wikipedia offers a more comprehensive study of the various neighborhoods of Tokyo than can be found in this game.   The game allows for currency conversions for all transactions in the game, ostensibly to fascilitate budgeting for a similar trip, but the usefulness of the feature is destroyed by how many costs are overlooked. That the protagonist lodges with a Japanese family--at no cost to him, one must presume--disregards one of the most significant expenses of a trip to Japan. Sadly, the greater preoccupation of the scenario writer was clearly the trite romantic comedy woven between the educational passages.  The music is servicable fare, limited to a handful of tunes that never become grating, if only due to the brevity of the game. Characters do not speak their lines, and aside from occasional sound effects, the background music is left to carry the scenes--a challenge far beyond its capacity.  A small offering of bonus features becomes availabe at the end of the first playthrough, though these provide little incentive to return to the shopworn storyline.  Fans of novelty and experimentation will find some redeeming qualities in what  Go! Go! Nippon! ~My First Trip to Japan~  has accomplished, but anyone looking for a captivating narrative or a useful resource for planning a stay in Japan would be better served by almost anything else.
